softwareCrimeTypes.name: Hacking
definition: Any action that results in unauthorised access to a system with the aim of causing damage or data theft
Write/use ready-made programs to break into a computer with intent to steal, damage, modify or monitor data within the system

softwareCrimeTypes.name: Spamming
definition: unsolicited emailing; can disrupt or disable networks

softwareCrimeTypes.name: Denial of Service Attack
definition: an attempt to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its intended users

softwareCrimeTypes.name: Sniffing
definition: electronic eavesdropping on electronic data transmissions; encryption vital to ensure security (e.g. HTTPS)

softwareCrimeTypes.name: Identity Theft
definition: The fraudulent acquisition and use of person’s private identifying information, usually for financial gain
examples: Phishing – fake (albeit credible) requests for confidential data
Skimming – details are stolen from magnetic strip or RF tag of a card
Shoulder surfing – direct observation of details e.g. being entered/displayed

compMisuseAct.title: Computer Misuse Act (1990)
compMisuseAct.description: Made it illegal to (attempt to) make unauthorised access or changes to computer material
compMisuseAct.origin: A direct response to a case in which two hackers were prosecuted for gaining unauthorised access (in 1984/5) to BT’s Prestel personal message service

actSections.title: Section 1
actSections.explanation: The basic offence of hacking (including failed attempts)

actSections.title: Section 2
actSections.description: Unauthorised access with intent to commit or facilitate commission of further offences
actSections.explanation: When the hacking leads to another offence (e.g. theft)

actSections.title: Section 3
actSections.explanation: covers the use viruses, worms; also phishing and skimming

compMisuseActAmendments.title: Amendments to CMA
compMisuseActAmendments.description: Sections 35 to 38 of Police and Justice Act (2006) contains some amendments
amendmentDescription: Section 3 offence is now defined as: Unauthorised acts with intent to impair, or with recklessness as to impairing, operation of computer, etc
Section 3A states that it is an offence to: supply or offer to supply any article believing that is it likely to be used to commit, or to assist in the commission of, an offence
Additionally, smart phones are redefined as 'computers' under the Act

privacy.title: Privacy
privacy.definition: The ability of an individual/group to stop data/information about themselves from becoming known to people other than whom they choose to give access
privacy.privacyTemp: It is increasingly tempting to use peoples’ data for purposes other than that for which it was originally collected (and therefore consented)
dataIssues: Data can be sold on to third parties
Data can be combined from different sources to build a profile of greater complexity than that originally visualized
Data might be inaccurate, or become so over time
privacy.solution: To counter these and other issues, the UK introduced the Data Protection Act (1994, 1998)

dataProtectionLegislation.title: Data Protection Legislation
description: The original act was first introduced in 1994
In 1995 the European Union (EU) approved the Directive on Data Protection (1995)
This led to key updates to the 1994 act concerning the obtaining and disclosing of data (in addition to data processing), forming the 1998 act
This act came into force on 1st March 2000

dpa1998.title: The Data Protection Act 1998
dpa1998.description: This act contains 8 key principles which have been edited for brevity
keyPrinciples: Personal data should be processed fairly and lawfully and only if necessary
Personal data shall be obtained for one or more specified purposes, and not processed further for other purposes
Personal data should be adequate, relevant and not excessive
Personal data should be accurate and kept up to date
Personal data should not be kept for longer than is necessary for the original purpose
Personal data shall be processed in accordance with the rights of data subjects under this Act
Appropriate technical and organisational measures shall be taken against unlawful processing, accidental loss, destruction or damage of personal data

Personal data should not be transferred to a country outside of the EU unless they ensure an adequate level of protection for the rights and freedoms of data subjects in relation to the processing of personal data
dpaAppliesToDataHeldOn: On computers or in computer-readable format
dpa1998.subjectRights1994: Under the 1994 Act, Data Subjects had the basic right to know what data was held about them
subjectRights1998: makes our data protection laws fit for the digital age in which an ever-increasing amount of data is being processed
empowers people to take control of their data
supports UK businesses and organisations through the change
ensures that the UK is prepared for the future after we have left the EU

gdpr.title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
description: The GDPR is a regulation in the EU law on data protection and privacy for all individuals within the EU and the European Economic Area.
It came into action on 25 May 2018.
It specifies how businesses and public sector organisations can handle the information of their customers.
It gives more rights and control over their information.

gdprApplications.title: Who Does the GDPR Apply To?
gdprApplications.shortDescr: The GDPR applies to processing carried out by organisations that operate:
appliesTo: outside the EU that offer goods or services to individuals in the EU.
gdprApplications.secondShortDescr: The GDPR does not apply to:
doesntApplyTo: certain activities including processing covered by the Law Enforcement Directive;
processing carried out by individuals purely for personal/household activities.

gdpr.subTitle: What information does the GDPR apply to?

gdprAppliesTo.name: Personal Data
examples: any information relating to an identifiable person who can be directly or indirectly identified in particular by reference to an identifier.
applies to both automated personal data and to manual filing systems where personal data are accessible according to specific criteria

gdprAppliesTo.name: Sensitive Personal Data
examples: Racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership;
Genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person.
Data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.

gdpr.exceptions: Personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences are not included.
gdpr.subTitle2: GDPR Principles related to personal data
personalDataPrinciples: processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to individuals;
collected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and not further processed in a manner that is incompatible with those purposes;
adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed;
accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date;
kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed.
processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security of the personal data.

dataSecurity.title: Data Security
dataSecurity.definition: The mechanisms that protect the data against intentional or accidental threats
breachExamples: Loss of confidentiality – rights of organisation to secrecy
Loss of privacy – rights of control over personal data
Loss of integrity – damage or loss of data
dataSecurity.riskResponsibility: As an IT professional you are likely to have responsibilities around preventing some or all of these kinds of risks

bcsLink.explanation: refers to the need to keep up with technological developments and relevant legislation

dpaLink.name: 7th Principle
dpaLink.description: Appropriate technical and organisational measures shall be taken against unauthorised or unlawful processing of personal data and against accidental loss or destruction of, or damage to, personal data.
dpaLink.importantNote: If you give someone’s data away, and you could have prevented it, you’re potentially in breach of the Act

threats.name: Hardware
examples: Data corruption due to power loss or surge

threats.name: Users
examples: Using another person's means of access

threats.name: Programmers/operators
examples: Program alteration (such as creating software that is insecure)

threats.name: Database
examples: Unauthorized amendment or copying of data
Data corruption due to power loss or surge

threats.name: DBMS and application software
examples: Failure of security mechanism giving greater access

riskReduction.name: Authorisation
description: Access controls govern not only access to data but how it can be used
Access determined by authentication process (e.g. user name and password)
User access controlled by the system administrator
Privileges specify which objects (e.g. folders/files, DB tables) a user needs to read/modify in order to do their job
Granting of unnecessary privileges should be avoided

riskReduction.name: Backup and recovery
description: Making regular copies data and (in DB system) the log-file (transaction history) that contains information about all updates to the database.
Backup window: The time during which the backup can occur
Full back-ups are time/space consuming are often done periodically with incremental or differential back-ups
extraInfo: backing up volatile data during busy periods can cause integrity problems.
If possible scheduled out of normal operating hours

riskReduction.name: Encryption
description: Use of an algorithm that encodes data using an encryption key, whereby data can only be decoded (made readable) with the decryption key
Brute force methods can ‘crack’ 64-bit encryption key quite quickly. 128-bit or longer keys should be more reliable for the foreseeable future

riskReduction.name: Firewalls
description: Server/router based software that controls external access to the local network

risksSummary.title: Stay Secure Summary
risksSummary.description: In conclusion, in order to stay safe and secure your digital world, you should:
stepsToSecure: Install a firewall and anti-virus software
Choose strong passwords and don’t share
